story:
Macmillan's Ambition:

We understand how cancer can affect people’s whole lives – health, money, family, job; everything. And, after more than 100 years of caring, we understand that the most important thing is to treat people as individuals, not patients.

So we take the time to understand the support people need to live their lives as fully as they can. From the moment of diagnosis and whenever we’re most needed, we’re here to help people find their best way through. Our help is totally focused on each individual person, so everyone receives the support that’s best for them.

How to get involved?

Donate to this page, then join the Irvine Yammer Group chat on 09/10/20 at 08:30, to post photos of yourself and/or your cakes.
Just click this link: https://tinyurl.com/y4v7nyqc.

What is the impact of donating?

  1. £52 could help run our Online Community forum for over an hour. Typically, that would give nearly 750 people affected by cancer both emotional and practical support.
  2. £250 could pay for five people living with cancer to attend a health and wellbeing event, providing them with the skills to improve the management of these areas in their lives.
  3.  £335 could pay for a Macmillan grant that helps a family affected by cancer take a holiday and enjoy precious time together.
  4.  £546 could pay for a Macmillan Social Care Worker for a week, helping patients, family members and carers manage the social and practical problems of living with cancer.
  5.  £1023 could pay for a Macmillan nurse for a week, helping people living with cancer and their families receive essential medical, practical and emotional support.

Hear it from the beneficiaries, click this video link: https://tinyurl.com/yyf933ds.

Finally, best of luck from all at SWAT. :)

Besides raising money for a good cause and in memory of my beloved Aunty Mal. I have also decided to go sober this October for myself.

In the middle of this pandemic, I got hit hard with depression and suicidal thoughts which leaded to a distressing breakdown for myself, feeling alone and worthless. I found comfort in alcohol, too much alcohol and I didn't like person it turned me into. That's not me! Making loved ones around me suffer for what I had become.

After weeks of misery and feeling so low I decided to get help, a small step but felt like the biggest achievement I could've done. I am now on the right path for a healthier and better lifestyle with all the love and amazing support from family and friends. There are loads out there that can relate. It is only by speaking out we help ourselves and others around us.

Thank You for supporting not only my fundraising but myself too.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Hello, As some of you know, I have suffered with a number of conditions over the years. These conditions had left me in crippling pain and having to change my whole perception of how I wanted to live my life.

After being recommended to try a from of treatment, I can 100% say that I no longer suffer with these conditions, and am slowly getting my life back.

To show my gratitude, I really want to give back to try and help others and also get fit at the same time :-).

These are 2 charities that mean a lot to me, Macmillan Cancer support and fibromyalgia Action. Having just gone through a cancer scare and worrying what would happen to me or my family, if I had the diagnosis of cancer and these people help with that worry. 

Fibromyalgia action UK condition that so many suffer with and is still so very much misunderstood.  

And another charity that means a lot to my cousin as her daughter was diagnosed with diabetes at a very young age (and who gave me the inspiration for doing this challenge).

My plan, is to clock up a million steps in 3 months, starting on the 1st October 2020. This will mean that I will have to hit a target of over 10,000 steps a day for the next 90 days to reach my goal by 30th December. But I would like to push myself and achieve this may 1st December 2020. This may not be much for many of you, but for someone who is just getting back into life again, this will be a massive achievement for me.

If you have any spare pennies and you wold like to donate, very penny will spur me on and help me succeed in my goal to help these charities in these horrendous time for them and get me fit at the same time.

Unfortunately, our beloved mum passed on Tuesday 22nd of September, she was taken from us at the young age of 46. Mum was told she had terminal cancer in January and fought a long hard battle. 

Mum has left behind three children and two grandchildren who love her dearly. Mum was a very strong and loving individual who made her children the centre of her world. She raised three children singlehandedly and helped us to become strong and loving too. 

Mum spent her whole adult life supporting and caring for us and in her final years we got the chance to support and care for mum. 

We are heartbroken to have lost mum and thought we had a lot more time. Due to this we are asking for whoever can, to donate to Macmillan in hope of one day curing this vile disease so many more people like mum can live the long and happy lives they deserve.

Jaz, Richie and I are doing a 24 Hour Continuous Wattbike Cycle on the 10th December to raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support. Our aim is to cycle 280 miles from Frimley Park Hospital to the Defence Medical School in Lichfield within 24 Hours. Jaz, Richie and I will be cycling 2 hours on/4 hours off for 24 hours rotating between us. We will be supported by our military colleagues who will be rotating every hour for 24 Hours. The event will take place at Frimley Park Hospital in Surrey and will start at 0800 Hours and finish the following day at 0800 hours. This will be challenging for us both and everyone involved but it's all for a cause close to our hearts and we hope to smash our targets both money wise and mileage wise :).

pageSummary: Learning to run because I've realised how important my health is!
story:
In 2018, my dad had a heart attack. I was at work when I got the phone call from my mum (horrific). My manager let me return home straight away and he said something to me that day: "family is always the most important thing". 

How very right he is. This current pandemic has brought it all back to me - feeling hopeless in the face of something health-related, especially when it threatens your loved ones. 

Though I carry my dad's genes, I have no crystal ball that shows me having the same problems later in life. And yet! Why risk it?! 

So..! With lockdown, social distancing and working from home all taking their physical and mental toll on me, I've decided to do something positive for myself. I'm going to try and complete the NHS couch to 5k challenge, though I absolutely hate running! 

I'll share the pain along the way (har! har!) with updates on here about how I'm getting on, and I'd be grateful for any tips, puns, or general support from anyone to keep me on track until I get there!

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

story:
Citi are aiming to raise £350,000 to enable Guide Dogs to create 178 life-changing partnerships. With our support, Guide Dogs will match people with sight loss on the London waiting list to guide dogs or volunteer sighted guides.

This October, Citi colleagues are coming together to take on a 178 challenge to raise vital funds for people living with sight loss in London. To support this effort I will be running 178k (equivalent to more than 4 marathons) during the month....and attempting to shift approximately 17.8kg gained during lockdown.

About Our London Charity Partner Guide Dogs

Losing your sight shouldn't also mean losing your independence, confidence and freedom, but unfortunately, our world is a tough place when you cant see. In the UK, there are 360,000 people who are blind or partially sighted and half of them do not leave their homes alone.

Guide Dogs provide life-changing services:
- Guide Dogs
- Volunteer sighted guides (My Guides)
- Support for children and young people
- Orientation and mobility specialists
- Technology
- Support for friends and family

Your support is greatly appreciated.

pageSummary: I am running to fundraise for Cancer Research UK because No one should loose a loved one to Cancer
pageSummaryWhat: I am running to fundraise for Cancer Research UK
story:
WE NEED YOUR HELP!

We will all, at sometime in our lives, be touched by Cancer.

It is only through continued Research that new cures and treatments are discovered and improved.

My first Race for life on July 2015 was the 5km in the pouring rain.

It was 4 months after my treatment for Oesophageal Cancer finished and 20 months after we lost Kerry, my stepdaughter following her long battle with lymphoma. She was 27 and left a son who was not yet 3 years old.He is now eight years old and we miss her dreadfully.

At the time medical research was not as advanced as it is today.

Thank you to Cancer Research, the amazing staff at RDE and support from family, friends and FORCE in Exeter. Because of them I am still here and able to take part in the Race For Life.

I vowed to run, and keep running, to raise awareness (and hopefully money!) for this cause as hopefully in time nobody will lose a loved one to Cancer. The Pink Army is a reminder of how the effects of Cancer are devastating to both individuals and their friends and families and each year The Race For Life is very emotional and personal for me. I run because I can ,where others have not been so fortunate.

I progressed to the 10km the year after(2016) and this year I ran 10km again but this time at home due to the Civid restrictions, and around the river, lanes and fields of our lovely Devon countryside. It helped as it was fantastic weather! It was not as easy as it used to be and I am not very keen on running, so please give me some incentive. 

Please support my fund raising for Cancer Research UK.  In these difficult times I am acutely aware that we all are watching the pennies but every donation helps however small.

LET’S BEAT CANCER! TOGETHER WE CAN!

Thanks

Em x

Weve been caring for local people in this way for more than 50 years, now. Every single day at the hospice is an extraordinary day. We listen, support and give high-quality care during what can be a difficult, challenging and distressing time. And we get to know people as individuals, find out what makes them happy, and help to make those things happen.That might mean sitting with them in the hospice garden, or arranging for their pet to visit them at the hospice. We focus on the special things that bring people joy.We also provide important support for carers and families, including bereavement support and counselling.We need to raise £6,150 per day to run the hospice, so every penny counts. Thank you for helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in and around Belfast, get the care and support they need. story:
One year ago, my husband Simon's life was saved by the RNLI. 

But on land, not at sea. 

Simon is a crew member of the North Berwick Lifeboats. A routine medical examination performed by the RNLI doctor appointed at Dunbar, uncovered a heart murmur. Months later, Simon attended for a scan at East Lothian Community Hospital and was rushed immediately to the Edinburgh Royal Infirmary in an ambulance. He required major open heart surgery just days later to save his life. He was found to have a congenital heart condition which had caused life threatening damage. His aorta was at risk of rupturing, which as the consultant put it, would have been 'game over'. This was deeply shocking for our family, as Simon had not experienced any real symptoms that would suggest his life was at risk. We had rowed 13 miles along the Clyde in a St Ayles skiff the weekend before! 

If it weren't for the medical examination - made possible by funding and support from the RNLI for its crew - Simon would not be alive today.

Simon is back at Lifeboats now and continuing his training as helm. It's his way of giving back and more. I'd like to raise awareness for the RNLI and mark this one year moment of recovery for Simon. So I am raising money for the RNLI by running (I hate running) 10 x 5k, 5 x 10k and a half marathon, all in October.

More on the RNLI:

More than ever the RNLI need help. As a charity, they depend on our donations so that they can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
charity.registrationNumber: 288701 (England and Wales) and SC039479 (Scotland)
story:
I am currently President of Warrington Circle of the Catenian Association and have chosen WaterAid as my presidential Charity for 2020-2021

I was aware of Water Aid back in the days when water was a publicly managed utility in the UK, because every year my water rates included an appeal for the charity; which I usually ignored.

Then in 1992 I was n conversation with my cousin Fr. Felim
McAllister – who was a missionary priest in Sierra Leone.  He was back home on leave and we had several chats.  On one occasion he said "Most Foreign Aid gets wasted and does no good. The only people who do something positive are those who bring water to villages.  By installing a pump, they totally transform the quality of life for that community.” 

Those few sentences opened my eyes.  I could clearly picture what he was getting at, and I immediately began making donations to WaterAid.  Then some 18 months after that conversation Fr. Felim was dead – a victim of Sierra Leone’s dirty little civil war.  His death, doing the work he loved, inspired me to continue contributing which I have done ever since.  I call it my "charity of choice," and hence the obvious choice for my presidential year.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.
